statement:
If ${f:{X\rightarrow Y}}$ is a weak homotopy equivalence and $X$ and $Y$
are path-connected and of the homotopy type of CW complexes, then $f$ is
a strong homotopy equivalence.

It is essential to the theorem that isomorphisms between $\pi_k(X)$ and
$\pi_k(Y)$ for all $k$ are induced by a map ${f:{X\rightarrow Y}};$ if
an isomorphism exists which is not induced by a map, it need not be the
case that the spaces are homotopy equivalent.

For example, let $X={{{\mathbb R}}P}^m{\times}S^n$ and
$Y={{{\mathbb R}}P}^n{\times}S^m.$ Then the two spaces have isomorphic
homotopy groups because they both have a universal covering space
homeomorphic to $S^m{\times}S^n,$ and it is a double covering in both
cases. However, for $m<n,$ $X$ and $Y$ are not homotopy equivalent, as
can be seen, for example, by using homology: $$\begin{aligned}
H_m(X;{{{\mathbb Z}}/ 2{{\mathbb Z}}})&{\cong}&{{{\mathbb Z}}/ 2{{\mathbb Z}}}, \quad \textrm{but} \\
H_m(Y;{{{\mathbb Z}}/ 2{{\mathbb Z}}})&{\cong}&{{{\mathbb Z}}/ 2{{\mathbb Z}}}\oplus{{{\mathbb Z}}/ 2{{\mathbb Z}}}.\end{aligned}$$

(Here, ${{{\mathbb R}}P}^n$ is $n$-dimensional real projective space,
and $S^n$ is the $n$-sphere.)
